subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: My layout
msgSnippet: fctarbox3: I would propose that the half letters could be implemented through the use of the shift key, i.e. Peep on the key p and half-peep on
messageBody:
fctarbox3:

I would propose that the half letters could be implemented through the use of the shift key, i.e. "Peep" on the key "p" and "half-peep" on shift-"p".  The half-letters, as I have used them being "p", "b", "d", "t", "h", "y", "w", "hw", "s", and  "z".  All of these could be placed on their  standard qwerty key except for "hw", which would have to go elsewhere.

QS was designed to be easy to write in a connected manner without actual connectors.  That is, letters which can connect are permitted to, and if they don't naturally connect, that is fine also.  Many people probably assume that QS in a printed or computer font would be written as junior QS, i.e. with no letters connected to each other.  However, in my opinion, the natural ability of the letters to connect so gracefully should be utilized, and with computer fonts this can be done.  In particular, the half keys are important for producing some of the most distinctive word-shapes in QS.  Other connections such as "sp" and "sk"  and the vowel connections to a following "r" are so natural that is seems foolish not to use them when we have the technology to do so.  I do not believe that a computer font of senior QS is less legible than junior QS.  Does anyone here think that computer generated QS should be left unconnected?

I especially like the idea of the linkages being automated with a "delinkage" key being available to the writer to enable him to modify such linkages when it suits his pleasure.

Paige G.

fctarbox3 wrote:

 Sorry for the extremely delayed response.

Why do the half letters need their own separate keys?  The qwerty
keyboard has been pressed into service for writing Arabic, with
final, medial, initial, and isolated versions of most graphemes, as
well as numerous vocalic diacritics; and Kana, where long key
sequences lead to single characters.  This has forced the advance of
font technology where the exact glyph used in a word can be
determined by the computer, not the author.

Shouldn't a new font be taking advantage of this technology?

By being forced to write a rigorous set of rules for all the
linkages, we would also help disambiguate the precedence of the
different possible linkages, although this treads dangerously close
to reintroducing arbitrary "orthodox" spellings quickscript was
designed to avoid (instead of arbitrary spellings, however, they
would be more or less arbitrary "graphings")

Should an author truly desire to force non-regular glyph-breaks,
this is facilitated by the addition of a null glyph; a key that
produces no visible text, but breaks up the characters so that the
internal processor treats them separately.  For example, st,
commonly joined along the top in quickscript, would display
differently from s.t, which would separate the two with no other
change in visible display.  (The '.' would be a bad choice for a
null glyph, but it makes for a very legible example)

> People have asked if I'm going to take the
> half-letters into account as well as wondering what
> sort of "layout" I'm talking about.  I figure I'll
> kill two birds with one stone, and show you the layout
> I'm currently using.  Note: it is BASED upon a
> one-to-one of the sounds represented by TO, but not
> precisely on (as there are some letters that are
> redundant).  Where possible, I have used mnemonic
> links to make things easier.  Where not possible, I
> have simply paired up a likely pair of characters on
> one key (you will notice this with #39/#40.  I have
> ALWAYS tried to pair up characters in an intuitive way
> on the keys.  This is somewhat primitive (as I have
> drawn the characters by hand in lieu of a finished
> font), but hopefully you'll
> see what I'm getting at.
>
> NOTE: The dotted "boxes" represent that this character
> is a half letter meant to be above or below some other letter.
